In order to elucidate the special role of interfacial effect over nanomaterials in the catalytic oxidation of volatile organic compounds (VOCs), a series of core-shell Mn2O3@δ-MnO2 catalysts with different degree of oriented growth were prepared by a hydrothermal method, which were applied for methanol oxidation. Besides, the structure-activity relationship over the core-shell Mn2O3@δ-MnO2 catalysts was further explained in details by multiple characterization techniques. It was found that the strong metal-support interaction promoted the formation of the interface between Mn2O3 and δ-MnO2, which significantly changed the physicochemical properties and catalytic behaviours of core-shell Mn2O3@δ-MnO2 catalysts. Among all the catalysts, the catalytic performances of these core-shell catalysts were obviously better than those of pure δ-MnO2 nanosheets and Mn2O3 microspheres, and the Mn2O3@δ-MnO2-8h catalyst exhibited the best outstanding activity for methanol oxidation (T90 = 119 °C). In addition, the characterization analyses showed that the interfacial effect derived from the interaction between Mn2O3 and δ-MnO2 can increase the amount of Mn4+, and surface lattice oxygen, as well as optimize the low-temperature reduction ability, which was the crucial reason for the high activity of above core-shell Mn2O3@δ-MnO2 catalysts. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Manganese oxide Core-shell nanostructures Metal-support interaction Interface-engineered Surface lattice oxygen 1 Introduction With the development of modern industry and urbanization, the continuous emission of volatile organic compounds (VOCs) leads to serious environmental problems [1–4]. To date, such as absorption, adsorption, membrane separation, incineration, thermal catalysis, photocatalysis, biodegradation, and many other technologies have been widely used in the degradation of VOCs [5,6]. However, catalytic oxidation technology has been considered as an efficient and non-secondary technology for pollution VOCs treatment [7]. In recent years, metal oxides have shown more excellent application potential as the key catalysts for VOCs catalytic oxidation [8–11]. Moreover, precious metals (Au, Pt, Ag and Ru, etc.) are highly efficient in catalytic reactions due to their superior redox capacity, but their higher cost limits their widespread application [4,9,11,12]. Given, because of the cost, of industrial catalysts, most current studies have tended to improve the reactivity of non-noble metal catalysts [11,13–17]. As an important transition metal oxide, MnOx has attracted extensive attention in the fields of thermal catalysis, photodegradation and battery due to its special physical and chemical properties and low cost [18–20]. Since most catalytic reactions are mainly carried out on the surface of solid catalysts, the surface microstructures of manganese oxides are important variables that affect the catalytic activity and mineralization for VOCs oxidation [21]. It is reported that the various crystal structures and morphologies of MnOx have a good development space in the study of enhancing catalytic activity by specific modification [22,23]. In the related studies, manganese oxides with different morphologies, such as spherical, linear, hollow, flower-shaped, tubular and core-shell shapes, showed significantly different catalytic activity, as well as the close relationships between the structures and activities of MnOx catalysts were demonstrated [22,24,25]. Besides, the construction of core-shell catalysts has proved to be an effective measure, which can take advantage of strong interaction between the interface of composite materials to improve the catalytic performances [26,27]. The interface structure of core-shell materials is essentially composed of two or more component materials, whereby the inner material is partially or completely encapsulated by the outer material and possibly even chemically bonded to it, thus forming the boundary structure. Its advantages as follows: (i) Controlling synthesis of composition and morphology can change the physical properties of catalysts, such as specific surface area and porosity, and obtains the surface structure that is favorable to the reaction; (ii) These catalysts with core-shell structures could achieve functional complementarity of diverse materials, optimize and derive heterogeneous interface, and the active sites were diverse may be in the core or the shell (or both), or at the interface [21,27]. The metal-support interaction is a classic method to construct the interfacial structure of core-shell catalysts, because the metal-support interaction is considered to be the internal driving force to improve the performance of catalysts, and plays a key role in regulating the catalytic behaviour at the center of the interface [28,29]. The interface position actually acts as a bridge connecting the metal species and the support interaction, and this structure is more likely to cause the chemical properties and electronic structure changes of the active center, to improve the catalytic activity [26,30]. For example, Tang et al. prepared a novel core-shell MnO2@Co3O4 composite catalyst with excellent catalytic performance for HCHO removal, because the decorated hybrids had better low-temperature reducibility and more active surface adsorbed oxygen species [31]. Deng et al. prepared a novel core-shell MnO2@NiO composite catalyst, and the MnO2@NiO nanocomposite with better low-temperature reducibility and more active surface oxygen species exhibited much better performance in complete oxidation of benzene than that of the single MnO2 nanowires [32]. Other Mn-based core-shell catalysts, such as Fe3O4@MnO2 [33], CeO2@MnO2 [34], Co@Mn-MOF [35] and LaFeO3@MnO2 [36], also exhibited high activity in the catalytic oxidation of VOCs. Although the heterogeneous interface of different substances hybridization has a significant effect on the catalytic properties of Mn-based core-shell catalysts, the special effect of interfacial structure between pure manganese oxides on Mn-based core-shell catalysts is a lack of systematic research. On the other hand, the effects of surface decoration size and shape on the activity of catalysts remain to be further discussed. To achieve the above purposes, we attempted to construct a two-dimensional Mn2O3@δ-MnO2 core-shell structure to probe the synergistic effect of Mn2O3 microspheres and δ-MnO2 nanosheets in methanol oxidation. These core-shell catalysts were facilitated by introducing δ-MnO2 nanosheets into the surface of Mn2O3 microspheres and systemically investigate the special role of core-shell catalyst interfacial effect in methanol oxidation. In addition, the structure-activity relationship of the core-shell Mn2O3@δ-MnO2 catalysts was identified by various characterization techniques, including XRD, SEM, TEM, BET, H2-TPR, O2-TPD, TGA, EPR, and XPS. The related results show that this novel core-shell Mn2O3@δ-MnO2 structure catalysts showed much better activity for methanol oxidation than those of original δ-MnO2 nanosheets and Mn2O3 microspheres. 2 Material and methods 2.1 Catalyst preparation 2.1.1 Preparation of Mn2O3 Typically, NH4HCO3 (48 mmol) and 50wt.% Mn(NO3)2 (20 mmol) were dissolved into 100 mL deionized water, respectively. Then, the NH4HCO3 solution was added to the Mn(NO3)2 solution. After that, 6 mL ammonium hydroxide (25 wt.%) was introduced into the former solution with strongly stirring. Finally, the mixed solution was stirred at indoor temperature for 12 h. The final yellow precipitates were filtered and washed several times with deionized water and ethanol, then dried at 100 °C for 12 h. The yellow precipitates were heated at 400 °C for 4 h with a heating rate of 2 °C min-1 in air. The obtained sample is labeled as Mn2O3. 2.1.2 Preparation of δ-MnO2 Typically, KMnO4 (1.50 g) and MnSO4•H2O (0.28 g) were added into 80 mL deionized water to get a homogeneous solution, which was put into a 100 mL stainless steel autoclave, sealed and kept at 160 °C for 12 h. After cooled to indoor temperature, the as-obtained black precipitates were washed with deionized water and ethanol several times, and dried at 100 °C for 12 h. Finally, the black precipitates were heated at 400 °C for 4 h with a heating rate of 2 °C min-1 in air. The obtained sample is labeled as δ-MnO2. 2.1.3 Preparation of Mn2O3@δ-MnO2 Typically, KMnO4 (0.10 g) and Mn2O3 (0.10 g) were added into 30 mL deionized water to get a homogeneous solution, which was put into a 50 mL stainless steel autoclave, sealed and kept at 140 °C for 4 h. After cooled to room temperature. The as-obtained black precipitates were washed with deionized water and ethanol several times, and dried at 100 °C for 12 h. The obtained sample is labeled as Mn2O3@δ-MnO2-4h. In addition, the prepared samples on Mn2O3@δ-MnO2-6h, Mn2O3@δ-MnO2-8h and Mn2O3@δ-MnO2-10h were also synthesized by the same synthetic procedure under different hydrothermal times. The preparation of other core-shell catalysts is similar to that of Mn2O3@δ-MnO2-4h except for the hydrothermal reaction time. When the reaction time was 6, 8 and 10 h, the as-prepared samples were labeled as Mn2O3@δ-MnO2-6h, Mn2O3@δ-MnO2-8h and Mn2O3@δ-MnO2-10h, respectively. 2.2 Characterizations The characterization techniques used in the experiment and their related details, such as XRD, SEM, TEM, BET, H2-TPR, O2-TPD, TG, EPR and XPS, etc. are given in the supporting information. 2.3 Catalytic activity The catalytic activity test was carried out in a fixed-bed quartz tubular micro-reactor (Φ=6.0 mm) with 100 mg catalyst and 400 mg quartz sands (40–60 mesh). The volumetric composition of the reactant mixture was 1000 ppm methanol balanced synthetic air, and the total continuous flow was 100 mL min-1, corresponding to a weight hourly space velocity (WHSV) of 60 000 mL g-1 h-1. The range of temperature was 60 to 180°C. The concentrations of the reactants and products were monitored online by gas chromatography (Shanghai Fanwei GC-6600) equipped with two flame ionization detectors (FID). Methanol oxidation was also characterized by the CO2 generation rate: (1) η C O 2 = C C O 2 , out C methanol , in × 100 % Where η C O 2 , C methanol , in (ppm) and C C O 2 , out (ppm) are the CO2 productivity, methanol in the inlet gas, CO2 in the outlet gas, respectively. Catalytic activity can also be evaluated by comparing the apparent activation energy ( E a ) values of catalysts, a sample with a lower E a value in a catalytic reaction will possess excellent catalytic activity. It has been reported that VOCs combustion follows first-order kinetics at VOCs concentration less than 20% under the presence of excess oxygen with the equations: (2) γ = N methanol × η methanol W cat (3) γ = − κ c = [ − A exp ( − E a RT ) ] Where N methanol , W cat , γ , κ, A, and E a correspond to the C methanol gas flow rate (mol s-1), catalyst weight (g), the reaction rate (μmol g-1 s-1), rate constant (s-1), pre-exponential factor, and apparent activation energy (kJ mol-1), respectively. The κ values are calculated from the reaction rates and methanol conversions. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Synthetic process and XRD structural analyses As shown in Scheme 1, a multiple assembly procedure has been applied to synthesize Mn2O3@δ-MnO2 core-shell structures. Firstly, In the first step, ammonia water and ammonium bicarbonate were used as co-precipitators to react with manganese ions to prepare manganese oxide precursors, which were then calcined to form Mn2O3 microspheres. Then, the δ-MnO2 nanosheets formed by the decomposition reaction of potassium permanganate as the donor grew on the surface of Mn2O3 microspheres in situ, and the densities of the δ-MnO2 nanosheets covering the surface became denser with the time prolongation, forming a cross-network structure. As shown in Fig. 1 , X-ray diffraction (XRD) was used to investigate the crystal structures of the six samples. It can be found that the characteristic peaks of the Mn2O3 sample correspond to (211), (222), (321), (411), (332), (440) and (622) crystal planes of Mn2O3 (JCPDS card no. 71-0636), respectively, and its sharp and narrow peaks show that the Mn2O3 sample owns a better crystallinity [37]. The characteristic peaks of the δ-MnO2 sample correspond to (001), (002), (111) and (312) crystal planes, which are consistent with δ-MnO2 (JCPDS card no. 80-1098) standard [38]. By observing the diffraction patterns of above Mn2O3@δ-MnO2 core-shell samples, it can be observed that the characteristic peaks of (001), (111) and (312) crystal planes are attributed to δ-MnO2 (JCPDS card no. 80-1098). The characteristic peaks of (222) and (440) correspond to Mn2O3 (JCPDS card no. 71-0636). This indicates that the original peaks of Mn2O3 phase are still well preserved after the modification of the δ-MnO2 nanosheets. In the above core-shell samples, the crystal crystallinity of Mn2O3@δ-MnO2 samples obviously changes with the change of hydrothermal reaction time, which can be attributed to the different growth states of δ-MnO2 nanosheets. Furthermore, the diffraction peak of the Mn2O3@δ-MnO2-4h sample is relatively weaker due to a short hydrothermal time, resulting in the formation of incomplete δ-MnO2 nanosheets. Compared with pure Mn2O3 and δ-MnO2, the diffraction intensities of as-obtained Mn2O3@δ-MnO2 samples are obviously reduced, due to the interaction between Mn2O3 and δ-MnO2, which leads to the increase of lattice defects and the decrease of crystallinity [39]. 3.2 Morphological and microstructural analyses The morphology and microstructure information on the as-prepared samples was obtained by SEM and TEM. Fig. 2 shows the SEM images of as-prepared six different samples. As shown in Fig. 2a, the Mn2O3 product possesses a uniform microspheres morphology with average diameter of about 1.05 μm. As shown in Fig. 2b, δ-MnO2 has nanoflower morphology, which was built up of many interleaving nanosheets, and the thickness of individual nanosheets range from 20 to 25 nm. For the core-shell Mn2O3@δ-MnO2 samples, with the Mn2O3 as a support, the δ-MnO2 species in the form of nanosheets can be perfectly decorated on the surface of Mn2O3 microspheres to form a novel core-shell nanostructure. In the SEM images of Mn2O3@δ-MnO2 samples (Fig. 2c–f), with the size of δ-MnO2 decoration increases, the δ-MnO2 nanosheets upon Mn2O3 outer surface begin to agglomerate and even entirely cover the surface of Mn2O3 microspheres. At the same time, the core-shell samples showed similar spherical coral nanostructures, with special fold morphology and interface structure characteristics. It was reported that the fold morphology of the core-shell structure and the moderate scale gap between the shells can fully absorb VOCs so that the reactants can easily reach the surface of the catalyst [21,32]. Comparing this series of core-shell Mn2O3@δ-MnO2 samples, individual Mn2O3@δ-MnO2-4h, Mn2O3@δ-MnO2-6h, Mn2O3@δ-MnO2-8h, Mn2O3@δ-MnO2-10h microspheres have average diameters about 1.10, 1.20, 1.35 and 1.45 μm, respectively. This indicates that the growth height and density of δ-MnO2 nanosheets increase with increasing hydrothermal reaction time. Obviously, the different growth states of the surface structures over these core-shell Mn2O3@δ-MnO2 catalysts affect the formation of the surface activity sites, as well as the adsorption and diffusion capacities of methanol. Fig. 3 shows the TEM images of as-prepared Mn2O3, δ-MnO2 and Mn2O3@δ-MnO2-8h samples. Fig. 3a confirms that the Mn2O3 microspheres morphology was composed by the aggregation of nanoparticles Mn2O3, with a microsphere diameter of about 1.05 μm, and individual Mn2O3 particles range in length from 20 to 35 nm, and preferentially exposes the (222) facets of Mn2O3. Fig. 3b shows the complex nanosheet structure of the δ-MnO2 sample, one typical kind of two-dimensional structure and preferentially expose the (001) facets of δ-MnO2. As observed in Fig. 3c, the TEM image of the Mn2O3@δ-MnO2-8h sample clearly confirms that numerous δ-MnO2 nanosheets are anchored on the surface of Mn2O3 microspheres, forming two-dimensional core-shell structure samples with a diameter of about 1.35 μm. It is also observed clearly that the epitaxial attachment growth of δ-MnO2 layer could be interconnected with Mn2O3 microspheres, which would lead to the creation of Mn2O3@δ-MnO2 interfaces. Besides, the nanosheet lattice fringes are calculated to be ca. 0.71 nm in Fig. 3c, corresponding to the d spacing of (001) planes of δ-MnO2 crystal [37]. This verified that the nanosheets on the core-shell catalyst surface are δ-MnO2 and preferentially exposes the (001) crystal face of δ-MnO2. The above microstructure information is consistent with SEM and XRD results. 3.3 Surface area analyses of catalysts The N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms and BJH pore size distribution curves of these catalysts were presented in Fig. S1. The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area results are summarized in Table 1 . According to Fig. S1a, the isotherms of all the samples belonged to the type IV isotherm, which was representatives of mesoporous materials [40–42]. For Mn2O3 in Fig. S1b, the H2-type hysteresis loop could be examined in the P/P0 scope of 0.5–1.0, this indicated the existence of a relatively uniform mesoporous structure in the spherical sampled [40]. For δ-MnO2 and Mn2O3@δ-MnO2 core-shell series samples, the H4-type flat hysteresis loops could be examined in the P/P0 scope of 0.4–1.0, which are mainly caused by the narrow mesoporous gaps between the hierarchical structures, indicating the existence of slit-like mesoporous structures in the samples [25]. Compared to those of the δ-MnO2 samples, the slopes of the adsorption-desorption isotherms on the core-shell Mn2O3@δ-MnO2 samples increased at higher pressures and the closed dot shifted to a lower value, which indicated that the micropores and mesopores formed and the macro-pores disappeared, which led to an increasing of the surface area [43,44]. Apparently, the pure Mn2O3 sample shows the greatest specific surface area and pore volume among all the manganese oxides samples. After different growth state of δ-MnO2 decorated on the outer surface of Mn2O3 microsphere, there is a significant reduction in the specific surface area and pore volumes of Mn2O3 sample. As δ-MnO2 can cover the micropore orifice of original Mn2O3 to affect N2 entry into internal pores, so the physical properties are going to change. In addition, among all core-shell samples, Mn2O3@δ-MnO2-8h sample δ-MnO2 nanosheets have the best height and distribution, showing the largest specific surface area (about 41.72 m2 g-1) and pore volume (0.093 cm3 g-1), which is favorable for methanol adsorption and capture. The smallest average pore size (8.85 nm) indicates a low internal diffusion resistance, which is favorable for the diffusion of reactants and products. 3.4 Catalytic performance of catalysts To probe the potential application of core-shell structure Mn-based oxides, the methanol oxidation over all the above samples was carried out under the reaction condition of 1000 ppm methanol balanced air, WHSV = 60 000 mL g-1 h-1 in the range of 50–200 °C, as shown in Fig. 4 . The catalytic activities of these core-shell catalysts are investigated by the T10, T50 and T90 values (corresponding to 10%, 50% and 90% methanol conversion to CO2, respectively). As shown in Fig. 4a, it can be found that the yield of methanol to CO2 increases with the increase of reaction temperature. The activity is decreased by the followed order of Mn2O3@δ-MnO2-8h > Mn2O3@δ-MnO2-10h > Mn2O3@δ-MnO2-6h > Mn2O3@δ-MnO2-4h > δ-MnO2>Mn2O3. The Mn2O3@δ-MnO2-8h catalyst has the best catalytic activity for CH3OH oxidation, and its T10, T50, T90 are 68, 104 and 119 °C, respectively. The Mn2O3 catalyst has the lowest activity, and the T10, T50, T90 are 112, 133 and 147 °C, respectively. Furthermore, the complete inorganic mineralization of CH3OH into CO2 and H2O can be realized by Mn2O3@δ-MnO2-8h catalyst at a temperature of 130 °C under a space velocity (WHSV) of 60 000 mL g-1 h-1. In addition, the catalytic activity can also be evaluated by the apparent activation energy (Ea) values of catalysts, a sample with a lower Ea value in a catalytic reaction will possess excellent catalytic activity [45–47]. As shown in Fig. 4b, the Ea values of these catalysts can be calculated by the Arrhenius diagram. The order trend of Ea values on these catalysts is followed as Mn2O3 (85.17 kJ•mol-1) > δ-MnO2 (66.13 kJ•mol-1) > Mn2O3@δ-MnO2-8h (35.63 kJ•mol-1), thus following an inverse trend with respect to the catalytic activities of methanol oxidation. The Ea values of all the catalysts are shown in Table 1. In this study, the stability of Mn2O3@δ-MnO2-8h sample was tested at 130°C, and the results are shown in Fig. S2. The removal rate of methanol remained about 100% during the whole period of detection. The activity of Mn2O3@δ-MnO2-8h catalyst did not decrease obviously, which indicated that the catalyst had good reaction stability. At the same time, it was found that the catalyst showed excellent CO2 catalytic selectivity during the reaction process. 3.5 Redox behaviour and oxygen adsorption analyses To investigate the activity and distribution of surface species on these catalysts, both H2 temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) and temperature programmed desorption of oxygen characterization technology (O2-TPD) spectra analysis were carried out on these catalysts, as displayed in Fig. 5 . The reducibility of catalytic materials is closely related to the surface oxygen species activity of catalysts, which is one of the important indicators of catalysts [31,32]. From the previous reports, two main reduction processes are usually applied to explain the reducing reaction of manganese oxides in the presence of hydrogen [37,48]. Firstly, MnO2 is reduced to Mn2O3 or Mn3O4 at low temperatures, that is, the process in which Mn4+ electrons are converted to Mn3+ (marked as RI). Secondly, Mn2O3 or Mn3O4 is further reduced to MnOx at the higher temperatures, and Mn3+ will be converted into Mn2+ at this stage (marked as RII). However, both two processes may take place at a certain range of temperature which would combine the reduction peaks together [31]. As shown in Fig. 5a, it can be clearly observed that there are several asymmetric reduction peaks in the graph. For Mn2O3 sample, the reduction peaks at 228 and 276 °C in the RI region corresponds to the reduction of MnO2 to Mn2O3 or Mn3O4 (Mn4+ to Mn3+), and the peak at 308 °C in the RII region correspond to the deep reduction of Mn3O4 to MnO (Mn3+ to Mn2+). For the δ-MnO2 sample, there is a broad reduction peak (RI region) with a maximum H2 consumption at about 284 and 299 °C, corresponding to the overlapping reduction of MnO2 to Mn2O3 and Mn2O3 to Mn3O4; the latter peak (RII region) in the range of 300-450 °C is ascribed to the contribution on the deep reduction of Mn3O4 to MnO. In addition, the reduction peak (RI region) of Mn2O3@δ-MnO2-8h is obviously different from that of δ-MnO2 and Mn2O3, shift slightly to lower temperatures (194 and 223 °C), suggesting the presence of highlighted synergistic effect between Mn2O3 and δ-MnO2, which interfacial structure enhances the low temperature reduction ability of Mn2O3@δ-MnO2-8h catalyst. Based on the oxidation mechanism, the reducing temperature is highly associated with the activity of oxygen species on catalysts. When the catalyst has excellent low temperature reducibility, on the surface of the catalysts to form easily active oxygen substances [31,39], which will help the catalytic oxidation of volatile organic compounds on the catalyst surfaces. According to the O2-TPD curve desorption features, three regions can be discerned: one at below 200 °C (OI region), one at about 200–450 °C (OII region), and another in the range of 450–700 °C (OIII region), which correspond to weakly bound surface reactive oxygen species (Oads), surface lattice oxygen species, and lattice oxygen species (Olatt), respectively [49,50]. Surface lattice oxygen species are more active than lattice oxygen species during VOCs catalytic oxidation [51]. From the peak analysis in Fig. 5b, it can be observed that there are obvious differences in active oxygen species on the surfaces of three materials. The main desorption peak of Mn2O3 is at about 540 °C, which belongs to the deep analysis of lattice oxygen in OIII region. And there is no peak in the low temperature region, which is related to the high concentration of Mn3+ [39]. For the δ-MnO2 sample, there are two weak surface lattice oxygen desorption peaks at 273 and 385 °C in the OII region, and another wide peak is located in the OIII region. The difference is that the Mn2O3@δ-MnO2-8h shows a more complex desorption peak. The peak at 143 °C in the OI region corresponds to the desorption of the adsorbed oxygen on the surface, the peak at 275 and 386 °C in the OII region corresponds to the desorption of the surface lattice oxygen, and the peak at 518 °C in the OIII region corresponds to the deep desorption of lattice oxygen. For the Mn2O3@δ-MnO2-8h sample, the amount of reactive oxygen species (OI region) is larger than that of Mn2O3 and δ-MnO2 samples, as well as its first O2 desorption peak (∼275 °C) of OII region is obviously increased due to the contribution on the migration of O2 desorption peak at about 386 °C. Further comparison of the three samples showed that Mn2O3@δ-MnO2-8h catalyst exhibits two stronger desorption peaks at 143 and 275 °C, respectively. This phenomenon indicates that the interfacial effect of Mn2O3 and δ-MnO2 interaction promotes the generation of reactive oxygen species on the surface of Mn2O3@δ-MnO2-8h catalyst, which is easier to desorption and is conducive to oxygen migration and transformation. The effect of Mn2O3@δ-MnO2 interfacial structure formed by metal oxide - carrier interaction on different oxygen species was confirmed. The results show that there is a strong interaction between Mn2O3 and δ-MnO2 carrier, which improves the transfer of lattice oxygen. 3.6 Thermogravimetric and oxygen vacancy analyses Both the Mn2O3, δ-MnO2 and Mn2O3@δ-MnO2-8h samples were further characterized by nitrogen thermogravimetric analysis (N2-TGA) to verify the surface reactive oxygen species that are beneficial for methanol oxidation, as shown in Fig. S3. The weight loss of Mn2O3, δ-MnO2 and Mn2O3@δ-MnO2-8h catalysts before 200 °C is due to the desorption of oxygen or hydroxyl substances adsorbed on the surface of the catalyst [39,52]. The first weight loss occurs at 160 °C, and the weight loss rates of Mn2O3, δ-MnO2 and Mn2O3@δ-MnO2-8h catalysts are 3.56 wt%, 2.75 wt% and 7.46 wt%, respectively. The weight loss ratio of Mn2O3@δ-MnO2-8h samples is obviously higher than that of Mn2O3 and δ-MnO2 samples. At higher temperatures (200–500 °C), palpable weight loss is observed, attributed to the loss of surface lattice oxygen [53]. At this stage, the weight loss of Mn2O3 and δ-MnO2 samples are relatively low, and the maximum weight loss for Mn2O3@δ-MnO2-8h due to the was approximately 12.35 wt%. Importantly, the weight loss for Mn2O3@δ-MnO2 was higher than that for Mn2O3 and δ-MnO2 during the heating process in 100–500 °C; this indicated that more oxygen species can be easily released from Mn2O3@δ-MnO2 catalyst surface in air than Mn2O3 and δ-MnO2 catalysts. The result is in good agreement with the above mentioned O2-TPD measurement results; this confirms that the interfacial effect of Mn2O3 and δ-MnO2 interactions can significantly enhance the activation of the surface oxygen species for methanol oxidation. In addition, the higher temperature above 500 °C is mainly due to the loss of lattice oxygen [39]. At this stage, the mass of δ-MnO2 and Mn2O3@δ-MnO2-8h tends to be stable, and the weight loss is less. The difference is that the Mn2O3 sample showed significant weight loss in the range of 470 to 550 °C, the temperature values of the weight loss are in accordance with the O2-TPD investigation results. Therefore, it can be attributed to the loss of deep lattice oxygen and the instability of manganese trioxide under high temperature conditions. In addition, the relationship between oxygen vacancy and activity was verified by EPR characterization test. Previous studies have shown that the formation of oxygen vacancies is closely related to the chemical valence states on the surface of the catalyst and the desorption of lattice oxygen [43,54,55]. As shown in Fig. S4, all samples exhibit a similar EPR signal (g = 2.002) that is attributed to the electron content trapped in O-vacancies [56,57]. The EPR signal intensity of Mn2O3 sample is higher than that of δ-MnO2 and Mn2O3@δ-MnO2-8h, respectively, indicating that O-vacancies are more abundant. TG and O2-TPD analysis showed that the surface lattice oxygen of Mn2O3 did not desorb at low temperature, so the abundant oxygen vacancy of Mn2O3 could be attributed to the high concentration of Mn3+. The weak EPR signal of δ-MnO2 indicates a low number of oxygen vacancies, which may be related to their high Mn4+ and lattice oxygen concentrations. For the Mn2O3@δ-MnO2-8h sample, as δ-MnO2 nanosheets can clog the oxygen vacancy of original Mn2O3 microspheres, and the interfacial structure of Mn2O3 and δ-MnO2 interaction promotes the generation of lattice oxygen and reduces the formation of oxygen vacancy, so the content of oxygen vacancy on the surface of Mn2O3@δ-MnO2-8h is much lower than that of Mn2O3. Therefore, combined with the analysis results of EPR and TG, it is considered that the high-valent Mn4+ and lattice oxygen may be the important reasons for the higher activity of Mn2O3@δ-MnO2-8h catalyst in low-temperature methanol catalytic oxidation. 3.7 Surface chemical nature analyses To further determine the form of the active oxygen species present and the oxidation state of metal elements on the surface of catalysts, XPS analysis was carried out, and the results are shown in Fig. 6 . As revealed in Fig. 6a, the binding energies (BE) at 643.2, 641.9 and 640.8 eV are ascribed to the surface Mn4+, Mn3+ and Mn2+ species, respectively [41,58]. As well known that the catalytic oxidation activity of Mn-based catalyst is associated with the extent of Mn4+ ↔ Mn2+ redox process. A higher molar ratio of surface Mn4+/(Mn3++Mn2+) indicates more redox cycles of Mn ions, and thus better catalytic oxidation activity [25,59,60]. The quantitative analysis with respect to the surface Mn4+/(Mn3++Mn2+) ratios of all of the samples is listed in Table S1. Obviously, it can be observed that the molar ratios of Mn4+/(Mn3++Mn2+) on the surfaces of the three catalysts are different. Mn2O3@δ-MnO2-8h possesses the highest surface Mn4+/(Mn3++Mn2+) molar ratio (around 0.898), whereas Mn2O3 shows the lowest molar ratio of surface Mn4+/(Mn3++Mn2+) (about 0.381). The sequence of the surface Mn4+/(Mn3++Mn2+) ratios for these catalysts is as follows: Mn2O3@δ-MnO2-8h > δ-MnO2 > Mn2O3. For the Mn2O3 sample, although the specific surface area is larger than δ-MnO2 and Mn2O3@δ-MnO2-8h, the content of Mn4+ is the lowest, which may be the main reason for the worst methanol oxidation activity. For the Mn2O3@δ-MnO2-8h sample, the ratio of Mn4+/(Mn3++Mn2+) is the highest, which should be due to the partial conversion of Mn3+ to Mn4+ due to the interfacial structure of Mn2O3 interacting with δ-MnO2 during the preparation process, which indicates that the interface plays a positive role in promoting electron transfer and the formation of Mn4+. The results show that the decoration of δ-MnO2 nanosheets on the surface of Mn2O3 microspheres can be promoting the bonding structures and electron transfers between metals and supports. Therefore, the redox cycle of Mn2O3@δ-MnO2-8h catalyst is enhanced, which improves the catalytic activity of methanol oxidation. In order to further explain the chemical state of the manganese oxide surface, the spectral analysis of Mn 3s should also be considered. The quantization of Mn 3s multiple splitting (ΔEMn3s) can provide a detailed explanation of the valence state of Mn ions. It is discussed in previous reports that the binding energy shifts to a lower value (MnO2 > Mn2O3 > Mn3O4) with decreasing oxidation state of Mn in the oxide, the value of ΔEMn3s shifts towards higher binding energies [46,61]. As shown in Fig. S5, compared with Mn2O3 and δ-MnO2, the peak of Mn2O3@δ-MnO2-8h is at the position of higher binding energy, and the order of (ΔEMn3s) from small to large is Mn2O3@δ-MnO2-8h < δ-MnO2 < Mn2O3. This indicates that the interfacial structure derived from the interaction between Mn2O3 and δ-MnO2 can promote the formation of more Mn4+ on the surface of Mn2O3@δ-MnO2-8h catalyst and reduce the ΔEMn3s value, which is also one of the important reasons for its higher activity. Meanwhile, the O 1s XPS spectra of Mn2O3@δ-MnO2-8h sample were also analyzed to prove the influence role of the synergetic interaction between Mn2O3 and δ-MnO2 towards surface-active oxygen species, as shown in Fig. 6b. The asymmetrical O 1s XPS spectra can be deconvoluted into three parts which represent three different oxygen species including surface lattice oxygen species (Olatt) at the lowest BE value, adsorbed oxygen species (Oads) and adsorbed -OH groups or molecular water at the highest value [31,49]. The distribution of oxygen species and a molar ratio of Olatt/Oads are calculated by a quantitative analysis technique and summarized in Table 2. As shown, the fraction of Olatt/Oads decreased in the order of Mn2O3@δ-MnO2-8h (4.215) > δ-MnO2 (3.982) > Mn2O3 (2.603). The surface lattice oxygen is also considered as a highly active species that can be firstly used and recycled during the catalytic oxidation reactions [51,62]. For the Mn2O3@δ-MnO2-8h sample, the maximum Olatt/Oads ratio proves that the formation of an interface between δ-MnO2 and Mn2O3 can improve the activity of surface lattice oxygen, which is consistent with the O2-TPD and TG result. Fig. S6 shows the curves of correlation among the T90 values, Olatt/Oads for as-prepared different catalysts, which further confirms that the existence of interfacial structure (evidenced by a high surface Olatt/Oads) enhanced the catalytic activity for methanol oxidation. The enhanced Olatt/Oads can result from the coordinative environment of strong interaction between Mn2O3 and δ-MnO2. In summary, XPS measurement of surface elements (Mn 2p, Mn 3s and O 1s) of core-shell sample shows adornments of δ-MnO2 nanosheets on Mn2O3 microspheres not only promoted the formation of more Mn4+, but also greatly increased the surface lattice oxygen (Olatt) species through the synergistic effect of Mn2O3 and δ-MnO2, which could be the reasons for the higher catalytic performance of methanol oxidation on the Mn2O3@δ-MnO2-8h catalyst. 4 Conclusions In conclusion, to achieve the efficient degradation of methanol, we have developed a novel and simple synthesis method for successfully preparing Mn2O3@δ-MnO2 core-shell structures with different decorating sizes of δ-MnO2, and the interfacial effect between δ-MnO2 nanosheets and Mn2O3 microspheres was studied, as well as its decisive roles in methanol catalytic oxidation. Experimental results confirmed that the results show that the strong interaction between δ-MnO2 and Mn2O3 support is an important internal driving force to improve the catalytic performance of core-shell Mn2O3@δ-MnO2 catalyst. The interfacial structure of Mn2O3@δ-MnO2 plays a key role in the catalytic behaviour and can effectively improve the chemical properties and electronic structure of the active center. In all samples prepared, reaction activity is decreased by the followed order of Mn2O3@δ-MnO2-8h > Mn2O3@δ-MnO2-10h > Mn2O3@δ-MnO2-6h > Mn2O3@δ-MnO2-4h > δ-MnO2 > Mn2O3. Among them, the Mn2O3@δ-MnO2-8h catalyst with optimal sizes δ-MnO2 exhibits with abundant specific surface area and a well-defined smallest mesoporous structure exhibited best catalytic activity for total methanol oxidation (T90 = 119 °C), which are significantly superior to those of other core-shell Mn2O3@δ-MnO2 catalysts. Additionally, the characterizations analysis demonstrated that the synergistic effect of δ-MnO2 nanosheets and Mn2O3 microspheres is the key to enhance deep methanol oxidation, which can be ascribed to the Mn2O3@δ-MnO2 interfacial structure exhibited more Mn4+, well redox ability and active surface lattice oxygen. Therefore, this work can provide a reference value for the systematic study of the interfacial structure to improve the catalytic activity. coredata.dc:description: In order to elucidate the special role of interfacial effect over nanomaterials in the catalytic oxidation of volatile organic compounds (VOCs), a series of core-shell Mn2O3@δ-MnO2 catalysts with different degree of oriented growth were prepared by a hydrothermal method, which were applied for methanol oxidation. Besides, the structure-activity relationship over the core-shell Mn2O3@δ-MnO2 catalysts was further explained in details by multiple characterization techniques. It was found that the strong metal-support interaction promoted the formation of the interface between Mn2O3 and δ-MnO2, which significantly changed the physicochemical properties and catalytic behaviours of core-shell Mn2O3@δ-MnO2 catalysts. Among all the catalysts, the catalytic performances of these core-shell catalysts were obviously better than those of pure δ-MnO2 nanosheets and Mn2O3 microspheres, and the Mn2O3@δ-MnO2-8h catalyst exhibited the best outstanding activity for methanol oxidation (T90 = 119 °C). In addition, the characterization analyses showed that the interfacial effect derived from the interaction between Mn2O3 and δ-MnO2 can increase the amount of Mn4+, and surface lattice oxygen, as well as optimize the low-temperature reduction ability, which was the crucial reason for the high activity of above core-shell Mn2O3@δ-MnO2 catalysts.
coredata.dc:title: Oriented growth of δ-MnO2 nanosheets over core-shell Mn2O3@δ-MnO2 catalysts: An interface-engineered effects for enhanced low-temperature methanol oxidation
